sourceDesc.p: The original source for this dataset is a database dump by the Bodleian Libraries at .

org.note: Married Ann Fennimore, 24 March 1695. Son of Thomas Ubank. Quaker.
Son of Thomas Udall of Ireleth, Lancashire, yeoman

address.addrLine: Knave of Spades, Upper Moorfields, Shoreditch

org.note: Maker's mark: The Knave of Spades (1707). Apprentices: John Thompson (1688); Samuel Dukeson (1697/8); Robert Durrance (1699); Joseph Powell (1704); William Adkinson (1705); Rees Jones (1706); Henry King (1708); Thomas Jarvis (1708/9); William Alphy (1713).
Born Exeter Heavitree. Wife of Samuel PP. Ch born 1820 Pilton, 1822 Holy Trin, 1828 Topsham
Born Exeter Holy Trinity. Dau of Samuel R and Ann I papermaker. Unmarried 1851
Born Topsham. Dau of Samuel R and Ann I, papermakers. Unmarried 1851

address.addrLine: Holy Trinity (1823). 43 Weirfield Pl, St Leonard (1851)

org.note: Printing-material manufacturer, printers' broker. Part Edwin Ullmer
Printers' brokers, manufacturers of printers' materials & dealers in new & second-hand presses & type.
Founded (1753) by Associates of Dr Bray; 216 books in 1785
Stephen Tyson and John Soulby, keepers (respectively)
Earliest known book club in Cartmel & Furness.
Also known as Colyton Mill or Coles' Mill
Successor to bro Leonard Umfreville. Trading as Umfreville & Co 1737
Agent for `Law Journal'. Possibly the same as John Underhill.

Son of Edward Underhill of Greenborough, Warwickshire

org.note: Apprenticed to Josiah Allen; pupil of Samuel Lines. Possibly first lithographer in Birmingham. Possibly bankrupt 1837

address.addrLine: St Edward's La (1837). Free School La (1843)

Son of George & Ann Unett; successor to Ann; succeeded by sister Sarah
Dau George & Ann Unett; successor to bro Richard Unett

org.note: Weekly. First issued 6/2/1759. Possibly existed for two years. AKA 'Halifax Advertiser'
WING C373; ESTC t048717. Took subscriptions for Camden's `Britannia' (1693); sold Stoughton's elixir (1712?). Possibly the same as Richard Unett
Formed by merger of New Public Library & Suffolk Public Library 1806

org.orgName: UNIVERSAL MAGAZINE OF KNOWLEDGE AND PLEASURE

org.note: Also known as 'Polite Magazine of History, Politics and Literature' originally published by Thomas Durham, taken over by John Payne in 1765.
Launched Spring 1760. Published or edited by John Scott.
Widow of John Unsworth, buried 19 Aug 1688. She was buried 14 February 1699(70). maiden name SANDERSON

org.note: Not the same person as the Matthew Unwin who traded in Leicester, though they could be related.
Also in Leicester & Loughborough. Not the same person as Matthew Unwin in Birmingham.
Also in Leicester & Ashby-de-la-Zouch. Not the same person as Matthew Unwin of Birmingham.
Not the same person as Matthew Unwin of Birmingham, though they could be related. Apprenticed to John Ward. 1. See note on 'A Nottingham catalogue printed in Leic.'. See also Unwyn.
Apprenticed to John Ward. 1. See note on 'A Nottingham catalogue printed in Leic.'. See also Unwin.
Mill first worked by Company of White Paper Makers c1690. See S Willey, D Rousillon, G de Vaux, T L Dummer, H Ball, J Gater, William H Gater, Ed Gater
Vestry clerk. Possibly husb Sarah Ann Upcher. Registered press 2/9/1833
grist mill in 1784. To let in 1771 & 1784 (as paper & grist mills in 1784). See Charles Warren, Chris Browne
